item.title: Post installation
item.description:
SysRq

Make sure to have this enabled in case there is some freeze in the system.

https://www.maketecheasier.com/the-usage-of-sysrq-key-in-linux/

Fedora explanation: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA/Sysrq

linux.fi: https://www.linux.fi/wiki/SysRq

wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic_SysRq_key

arch: https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Keyboard_shortcuts#Terminal

Update the system

# Debian based (Ubuntu, Mint, etc.)
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade

# Red Hat based (e.g. Fedora, CentOS, etc.)
sudo dnf update

Install additional programs

Program Description
htop Fancier version of top, Interactive process viewer
vim-* Text editor with improved enhancements/scripts
git the stupid content tracker 1
ansible IT Automation
gimp image manipulation and paint program
tmux terminal multiplexer
atom hackable text editor (graphical)
thonny Beginner’s python IDE (without the distractions and with great debugger)
zsh the Z shell

Available in the repositories

# Debian based (Ubuntu, Mint, etc.)
sudo apt install htop vim-scripts git ansible gimp tmux zsh

# Red Hat based (e.g. Fedora, CentOS, etc.)
sudo dnf install htop vim-enhanced git-all ansible gimp powerline tmux zsh

atom

Seeing as atom isn’t in most repos manual installation is required.

Go to https://atom.io/ and select the appropriate filetype.

To install the RPM:

# this will also pull down dependencies
sudo dnf install /path/to/atom-install-file.rpm

Ctrl+Shift+p opens the command palette. Can type Welcome to rerun the welcome guide.

thonny

Don’t do this just use the script

You can check if the package is available by typing:

pip3 search thonny

To install it:

Check on an Ubuntu machine and see where it actually installs thonny to

# Ubuntu - Installs to .local/bin
pip3 install thonny

# Fedora - get error if not using sudo
sudo pip3 install thonny

#This will require installing tkinter which starts getting messy easier to use the bash script located on the site to do the install

/Don’t do this just use the script

Adding to PATH

You should be able type the command in the terminal (Probably best to always start it from a terminal rather than creating a launcher; that way if there is an infinite loop or something it is real easy to terminate the program)

If it isn’t a recognized command then check if its path is included in your $PATH by typing in:

echo $PATH

If not then add it by going to your profile file (~/.profile, ~/.bash_profile) and look for the line that starts with PATH= then appending to the line :/path/to/thonny's/directory

If you don’t have one you could add one by doing something like this:

PATH=$PATH:$HOME/.local/bin:$HOME/bin

export PATH

Notes

1

At the time of writing git-all is broken for Debian based systems so using git instead.

item.title: XFCE
item.description:
Backup panel configuration

Open up the Xfce Panel Switch:

Once you’ve customized your panel to your liking select Save configuration it is the button to the right of the gears near the bottom left. Give it a name and then select it and click Export (fourth icon).

To import it, click the Import button (fifth icon) then Apply Configuration (first icon; the gears).

Keyboard settings

Application Shortcuts

Once at the keyboard settings, click on Application Shortcuts.

Change these commands’ shortcuts to:

command shortcut
xfce4-appfinder Ctrl+Space or Super+Space
xfce4-terminal Super+t
Thunar Super+f
exo-open –launch WebBrowser Super+w

Keyboard shortcuts to add:

command shortcut
xflock4 Super+L
xfce4-screenshooter -f -m -d 5 Super+5
atom Super+a
VirtualBox Super+v
xfce4-screenshooter -w Alt+Print (is this already there ?)

Now there are three shortcuts to lock the screen (xflock4) the other two are Ctrl+Alt+Delete and Ctrl+Alt+l

The screenshot command takes a screenshot of the whole screen -f, captures the mouse cursor -m and waits 5 seconds before taking it. -d 5

Layout

Unselect Use system defaults then under Change layout option: Alt+Caps Lock.

Window Manager Tweaks

Menu → Settings → Window Manager Tweaks → Accessibility tab

To be able to scroll in a non-focused window without changing focus: Uncheck Raise windows when any mouse button is pressed.

Questionable change

Change Key used to grab and move windows: to Super

Panel

My preference is one panel so delete any other panels if they exist. I prefer the traditional looking panels too so if one looks like the macOS bar get rid of that one.

Display

F1:
The defaults are fine for my one of two favorites.

F2:
For the other then change Row Size (pixels): to around 48.

Items

If Applications Menu is in use remove it (click on the -) and add (click the +) Whisker Menu and put at the top of the list if it isn’t already.

Add PulseAudio Plugin.

F2:
Select Window Buttons and then edit it (the button below the -). Deselect Show button labels.

Questionable change

Set Window grouping: to Always. This has the benefit of showing the title bar of all windows of the same type when you click on its icon on the bar instead of having to hover over each one to see which is which.

Add Screenshot a launcher next to themenu`

Window Manager

Keyboard

Action Shortcut
Maximize window Super+Up
Shade window Alt+Super+Up
Toggle above Ctrl+Alt+U (testing this out)
Tile window to the top Shift+Super+Up
Tile window to the bottom Shift+Super+Down
Tile Window to the left Super+Left
Tile Window to the right Super+Right
Tile window to the top-left Shift+Ctrl+Super+Left
Tile window to the top-right Shift+Ctrl+Super+Right
Tile window to the bottom-left Ctrl+Super+Left
Tile window to the bottom-right Ctrl+Super+Right

Questionable change

Advanced

Under Windows snapping check To other windows.

Other

Fix cursor not changing:
https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?id=131065

Clock

Right-click on the clock on the panel and select Properties. Set the Format: to Custom Format and set it to this format: <b>%T // %F // %a</b>
